author: m.kalinin
content:
I have been thinking for a bit about removing block fields that are being deprecated by the Merge. I believe that `extra_data`, `mix_hash` and `nonce` could be removed without breaking smart contracts that read block header fields as they are last three fields of block structure for the moment, after London the last one will be `base_fee_per_gas` but it is exposed by the `BASEFEE` opcode. The `difficulty` field is right before the `number`, so, removing it is potentially breaking change for this kind of contracts. 

And if we consider removing those three fields then `difficulty` would be a perfect place for `randao`.

cc <@!211091239112671234> <@!301186049323958275>

author: sky.cactus
content: `base_fee_per_gas` should still be present after The Merge.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, you mean that would be the last field in the header.

author: sky.cactus
content:
* I do think we need a plan for removing fields from header.
* I think we should set a very clear timeline on header shape changes and when they should be expected so people have ample time to migrate/adjust.
* I generally like the idea of separating The Merge from The Cleanup, and would rather have a bit of bloat for some months between the two than trying to do too much at once in The Merge.

author: m.kalinin
content: Yeah, removing fields is not necessary happening at the time of the Merge. And I'd rather consider this for cleanups too. But if we have a decision on doing this kind of cleanup (even after the Merge) then we better take it in consideration for the `randao` EIP. So, `difficulty` might still be the best place for `randao`. Though, there is a complexity with this kind of replacement.

author: axic3354
content: <@!301186049323958275> <@!425572898787426305> is it really that much easier hardcoding the fields as opposed to dropping them? Could the difficulty of dropping (i.e. all the code this affects) described in the EIP-3675 or its magicians forum?

author: axic3354
content: Or rather the complexity comes from adding new fields (randao) after dropping the old ones could be hairy, and better to do that in one step?

author: sky.cactus
content: The worry with changing the header layout is that we don't know exactly what tools might break.  Anything that does block validation has potential to break, which could be contracts validating merkle proofs, third party tools depending on merkle proofs, third party validating tools that aren't clients, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: It essentially extends the scope of things we need to worry about.  It is possible that it would be fine, but the cognitive overhead of determining that is likely high.

author: axic3354
content: Fair. I think this deserves its section in the rationale.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree with that.  cc <@425572898787426305> ☝️

author: m.kalinin
content:
Corresponding rationale section states the following (https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/a8dd00eeff5de6765084872ad30f45dcafcbcad9/EIPS/eip-3675.md#replacing-block-fields-with-constants):
> Deprecated block fields are replaced with constant values to ensure the block format remains backwards compatible. Preserving the block format aids existing smart contracts and services in providing uninterrupted service during and after this transition.

Isn't it kind of the same to what you have mentioned? <@!425279588009246720>  <@!301186049323958275>

author: sky.cactus
content: It may be valuable to have like one sentence that mentions that tools/contracts that validate block proofs (which includes anything that validates transaction/state/receipt proofs from a blockhash) will likely need to be updated when we change the block layout.

author: sky.cactus
content: Just to make it a bit more clear that this is not the same as changing an API or something.

author: _shemnon
content: High Goerli reorg count has nothing to do with 1559/London and everything to do with Clique. There is no leader node or leader elections (like the IBFT variants), so if the "in turn" block is too late all nodes that can should propose a next block, so seeing 4 reorgs at one block sounds like a clique network with 8 to 9 validators.
